Award.AwardTitle: Scholarships for Preparing the Global Engineer for Tomorrow's Workforce

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of the GE-STEM program at Tennessee State University (TSU) is to create an environment that supports the transformation of academically talented, yet financially needy students into Global Engineers (GE). The program has three academic pathways designed to equip 60 engineering students with the technical, professional and life-language learning skills required to succeed in tomorrow's workforce and in competitive graduate engineering programs. These pathways are aligned with strategies advocated by the National Academy of Engineering: Research, Retention, Responsibility, and Readiness. The project is creating a synergistic environment that leverages the success of existing on-campus professional development programs, and TSU's six federally funded programs focused on STEM student research success and ensure the project's sustainability. This synergy is supported by an advisory board with six directors of the STEM funded projects to share best practices and interchange of ideas to increase STEM student recruitment, retention, and graduate rates, and with local and regional support of middle Tennessee.

The GE-STEM project provides scholarships to students during their sophomore and junior years. GE-STEM scholars complete a formalized rotational research or professional development program through a global experience to better prepare for a professional engineering career. The professional development program provides students mentoring, peer-tutoring and pre-college counseling opportunities. Senior GE-STEM scholars who enroll in professional development programs are involved in organizing on-campus academic mentoring and tutoring sessions. GE-STEM scholars enrolled in the optional research programs are poised to engage in senior level research and enroll in competitive graduate educational programs. The research experience allows sophomore and junior level students to perform research activities in state-of-the-art facilities on topics such as nano-technology, vehicle human performance, visualization, sensor networking, material science and robotics. GE-STEM scholars present or publish their research and professional development experience and demonstrate their global learning via language competency or a foreign exchange experience. A Six-Sigma approach allows the GE-STEM project to monitor and control student academic success quantitatively.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the Global Engineering S-STEM project is to create an environment to produce a diverse cohort of Global Engineers (GE) to meet the needs of the 21st century technology workforce. The GE S-STEM project was implemented within the College of Engineering (CoE) at Tennessee State University (TSU), a Historically Black College and University (HBCU) with a dynamic and diverse engineering program. This goal is built upon the goals of the NSF-STEM project solicitation, a White House initiative from President Obama, and the recommendations of the National Academy of Engineers Grand Challenges for Engineering. The major objectives of the program were (1) Global Engineer Research Experience (GERE) – The objective was to transform TSU engineering students with technical, professional and life-language learning skills required to succeed in tomorrow’s workforce and/or in competitive graduate engineering programs. (2)  Professional Advancement of Global Engineers (PAGE) – The objective was to transform TSU’s College of Engineering students with professional development activities. Alternative pathways are available for this co-hort of 
S-STEM students to become Global Engineers. The pathways are built around Retention, Responsibility, and Readiness, and the outcomes of this initiative will help develop a culture of professionalism and promote student success and achievement.  (3) Infrastructure and Sustainability The objective was to transform TSU’s STEM environment by increasing the synergy between successful campus programs focused on STEM student achievement, and to leverage the existing programs for enhancing student success. The program activities included providing scholarships to academically talented and financially needy students in the College of Engineering.  S-STEM scholars participated in a undergraduate research experience by conducting research under the supervision of faculty researcher on federally funded research projects. S-STEM scholars also participated in professional development activities to improve their technical writing, resume preparation, job interview and graduate application preparation skills S-STEM scholars also participated in a study abroad programs which contributed towards their personal growth and encouraged them to develop new perspectives on world affairs. The significant results from the program were as follows. Since 2013, the program has provided 150 scholarships to College of Engineering students. Each student received $1000 - $5000 in financial support depending on the financial need. The S-STEM scholars consistently made the Dean’s List over 66 times. Participation in the GERE and PAGE programs helped secure over 63 internships for the S-STEM Scholars in industry, federal and academic research labs. Over 50 S-STEM scholars succcessfully completed their research tasks. All the S-STEM scholars attended one or more PAGE sessions. Selected students had the opportunity to travel to Turkey to participate in study abroad programs in Summer 2014 and Summer 2015.
